channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Opinion: Farewell, equid program
item.description: The U.S. Army announced that 141 of its 236 horses, donkeys, and mules will be put up for adoption, in a move it says will save about $2 million dollars.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. Army announced that 141 of its 236 horses, donkeys, and mules will be put up for adoption, in a move it says will save about $2 million dollars.

(Image credit: Mark Wilson/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: The week when crypto won big in America
item.description: Congress passed the first major crypto legislation in the U.S., marking a major milestone for the digital currency sector. And with President Trump's support, the industry plans to march on.
item.content:encoded:
Congress passed the first major crypto legislation in the U.S., marking a major milestone for the digital currency sector. And with President Trump's support, the industry plans to march on.

(Image credit: Brendan Smialowski)
item.dc:creator: Rafael Nam

item.title: Trump administration ends 988 Lifeline's special service for LGBTQ+ young people
item.description: Callers to 988 used to be able to press 3 to reach counselors specially trained to help LGBTQ+ young people. The service had been reaching 70,000 people a month.
item.content:encoded:
Callers to 988 used to be able to press 3 to reach counselors specially trained to help LGBTQ+ young people. The service had been reaching 70,000 people a month.

(Image credit: Smith Collection)
item.dc:creator: Rhitu Chatterjee

item.title: Congo and Rwanda-backed rebels sign declaration of principles for permanent ceasefire
item.description: Congo and Rwanda-backed rebels on Saturday signed a declaration of principles in Qatar to end fighting in eastern Congo that commits them to a permanent ceasefire to be signed in one month.
item.content:encoded:
Congo and Rwanda-backed rebels on Saturday signed a declaration of principles in Qatar to end fighting in eastern Congo that commits them to a permanent ceasefire to be signed in one month.

(Image credit: Moses Sawasawa)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Muddy boots and AI are helping this threatened frog to make a comeback
item.description: How do scientists monitor the populations of the threatened California red-legged frog? With careful listening and a little help from AI.
item.content:encoded:
How do scientists monitor the populations of the threatened California red-legged frog? With careful listening and a little help from AI.

(Image credit: Bradford Hollingsworth)
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: Are high-protein snacks worth the hype? Here's how to assess
item.description: Protein has taken over the packaged-snack aisles at the grocery store. But do you need extra protein in your chips and muffins?
item.content:encoded:
Protein has taken over the packaged-snack aisles at the grocery store. But do you need extra protein in your chips and muffins?

(Image credit: winterling/iStockphoto)
item.dc:creator: Reyna Gobel

item.title: The USDA wants states to hand over food stamp data by the end of July
item.description: The USDA has set a deadline of July 30 for states to hand over the sensitive data of tens of millions of people who applied for federal food assistance, while a lawsuit is trying to stop the collection.
item.content:encoded:
The USDA has set a deadline of July 30 for states to hand over the sensitive data of tens of millions of people who applied for federal food assistance, while a lawsuit is trying to stop the collection.

(Image credit: Mandel Ngan)
item.dc:creator: Jude Joffe-Block

item.title: Should you buy it? If you answer 'yes' to these questions, probably not
item.description: Sometimes we want to buy things we want, not what we need, and that's OK. When you're unsure whether to swipe that card or walk away, this guide can help you make a mindful decision you won't regret.
item.content:encoded: Sometimes we want to buy things we want, not what we need, and that's OK. When you're unsure whether to swipe that card or walk away, this guide can help you make a mindful decision you won't regret.
item.dc:creator: Marielle Segarra

item.title: New Texas law aims to save lives by clarifying the state abortion ban. Will it work?
item.description: In Texas, where abortion is banned, a bipartisan group of lawmakers, medical associations, and groups on either side of the issue worked together to clarify when abortion can be used in emergencies.
item.content:encoded:
In Texas, where abortion is banned, a bipartisan group of lawmakers, medical associations, and groups on either side of the issue worked together to clarify when abortion can be used in emergencies.

(Image credit: Gabriel C. Pérez)
item.dc:creator: Olivia Aldridge

item.title: Funding cuts will hit rural areas hard. One station manager explains how
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Tom Michael, general manager of Boise State Public Radio, about what the cuts to federal public media funding mean for his station.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Tom Michael, general manager of Boise State Public Radio, about what the cuts to federal public media funding mean for his station.
item.dc:creator: Juana Summers
